comment: Hi everyoneeeee! I'm so happy to see that so many of you can relate to what I said about hospitality at the end of the video. Every time I stay with a family in a new country, I do it in order to meet ordinary people from that country. I've always been fascinated with remote places and traditional village lives, and this is a wonderful insight into another culture.  ❤️

This video makes me remember my childhood memories.  Although I grew up in the city, on vacation my father always send me in the village .  The land of the ancestors. One day I went with my uncle to hunt rabbits. We were on horseback.  I fell off the mountainside and injured my neck.  Because of me, my uncle was reprimanded by my grandfather.  Another day, I went with some kids to get water .  Suddenly, it was raining.  Those boys left me with a family that I did not know.  So as not to catch a cold.  I remember how that lady treated me.  Like I was her son.  I changed my clothes, cleaned me and served me food.  In the Badia are people you cannot find in the world in which we live.  Unfortunately I can't go there anymore.  My grandfather and my grandmother are deads.  As for my uncle, he lives in the Netherlands

Merci ,fabuleusee Éva et permettez moi de vous nommer : " Femme du monde " . Le choix d'une famille du Maroc " profond " pour partager quelques moments avec elle ce n'est totalement facile vue les circonstances mais elle est sûrement possible pour des gens aventuriers comme vous chère Éva . C'est vrai que la vie de la famille choisie  est  en quelque sorte modeste , mais elle est pleine de chaleur , d' hospitalité et de générosité . Elle restera , si je peux dire ,une vie parmi d'autres  qui sont peut-être aisées mais qui manque de chaleur humaine . Le confort n'est pas toujours ce qu'on croit pour trouver les vraies valeurs sincères pour un vrai partage humain . J ' espére que ce voyage et ce partage marquera un bon  souvenir , loin de tout oublié , de ce pays plein de belles choses ,qui est le Maroc ma chère patrie .Je tire chapeau à cette famille hospitalière , je vous tire un autre également et je vous dis encore merci Éva - Femme du monde .💐

Learn some Amazigh words:
- Tanmmirt = Thank you
- Azul = Hello
- Ansuf (marhba) = welcome
- i7la = Beautiful
- sa7it or Ayyuz = Good
- Tamazigh = Moroccan language or amazigh female
- imazighen = Amazigh People
- Tamazirt = Country or village
* Aghrum = Bread
* Aman = water
* atay = tea
* lqahwa = coffee
if you need more words; just leave me a reply here ;) much love = uggar n tayri

The reality is we should be thankful to all indigenous people,wild animals and the Earth for the hospitality this planet provides us with, and to these people - for their healthy ways which in spoiled West are forgotten, resulting in diseases, wars and abuse among the members of the community. This us the greatest gift of your channel - it can help to preserve the sense of rawness we have to adopt in the cities and villages in the west, if we are to stay sustainable and healthy and actually lead good lives. It's sustainable to organize the society to experience a down to earth lifestyle, with the protection and help for basic survival provided by new technology. We have to learn to be more Berber in our homes and realize the hospitality and abundance of the Earth we are graced with in every season.

I'm not romanticizing either. Living a harsh life is usually healthier for your Spirit. the Tibetan people and indigenous communities of Latin America are other examples of what living in nature does to the mind and how simplicity and hardships in the physical reality, can be beneficial for the personal growth of humanity. It's not a formula, yet generally a lot of people become happier and healthier, leading a more simple, basic life.

On the other hand individuals who can't do that, may be expressing their gratefulness for what they already own more frequently, for us to have a balanced society and higher levels of satisfaction, living in modern day cities with lots of commodities. thank you for your videos

تعريف بالنبي محمد صلى الله عليه وسلم

#The_Prophet_Muhammad

Unlike the founders of many religious, the final prophet of Islam is a real documented and historical figure. He lived in the full light of history, and the most minute details of his life are known. Not only do Muslims have the complete text of God’s words that were revealed to Muhammad, but they have also preserved his sayings and teachings in what is called ‘Hadeeth’ literature.
This having been said, it should be understood that Muslims believe that the Prophet Muhammad was only a man chosen by God, and that he is not divine in any way. In order to avoid the misguided wish to deify him, the Prophet Muhammad taught Muslims to refer to him as ‘God’s Messenger and His Slave’. The mission of the last and final prophet of God was to simply teach that ‘there is nothing divine or worthy of being worshipped except for Almighty God’, as well as being a living example of God’s revelation. In simple terms, God sent the revelation to Muhammad, who in turn taught it, preached it, lived it and put it into practice.
In this way, Muhammad was more than just a ‘prophet’ in the sense of many of the Biblical prophets, since he was also a statesman and ruler. He was a man who lived a humble life in the service of God, and established an all-encompassing religion and way of life by showing what it means to be an ideal friend, husband, teacher, ruler, warrior and judge. For this reason, Muslims follow him not for his own sake, but in obedience to God, because Muhammad not only showed us how to deal with our fellow human beings, but more importantly, showed us how to relate to and worship God; worship Him in the only way pleasing to Him.
Like other prophets, Muhammad faced a great deal of opposition and persecution during his mission. However, he was always patient and just, and he treated his enemies well. The results of his mission were very successful, and even though his mission started in one of the most backward and remote places on earth, within a hundred years of the death of Muhammad, Islam had spread from Spain to China. The Prophet Muhammad was the greatest of all of God’s prophets, not because he had new doctrines or greater miracles, but because it was him who was chosen to bear the last revelation which would come to humanity from God, one suitable for all places, times, and people, everlasting and unchanging until the Last Day.

One day President Nixon wanted to read about "Islamic principles and rules", so he asked the CIA to prepare a research paper on the subject for me.
He wrote a research paper following the orders of his president, but it was a bit long ...
He asked his adviser, Robert Crane, to read and summarize the article.
Robert read the article and summarized it for the president, but the contents of the article forced Robert to do more research on Islam, so he attended Islamic seminars and conferences to learn more about the subject. Began to ...

Then came the day when Robert converted to Islam, inspired by Islamic teachings, and word of his conversion spread throughout the United States.

After converting to Islam, he changed his Islamic name to "Farooq Abdul Haq".

Explaining the reason for converting to Islam, he says:
As a law student, I found all the laws in Islam that I studied.
I studied law at Harvard University for 3 years but I never found the word "justice" in their law, however.
I have found this word frequently in Islam.

He converted to Islam in 1981 and named himself "Farooq" after Omar Farooq, who was the Imam of Justice after the Prophet.

He says: "Once we were having a legal debate. A professor of Jewish law was also with us. When it was his turn to speak, he began to speak and ridicule Islam and Muslims in his speech." Began to do .. When his demeanor began to exceed the limit, I decided to silence him ..
I asked him: Do you know the extent of inheritance law in the US Constitution?
He said: Yes, he has more than eight volumes.
I said: If I bring you a law of inheritance which is not more than ten lines, will you believe that Islam is a true religion?
He said: It is not possible that such a long and wide law of inheritance can be summed up in just ten lines ...
I extracted the verses of inheritance from the Quran and presented it.

This is an amazing footage! Thank you for sharing this beautiful experience with these amazing people, they are truly kind and very generous. I am from Tunisia, and I felt very connected to their habits and traditions. Khobz tabouna and zeit zeitouna (olive oil) are still one of our favorite snacks even though we live a more modernized life style. However, even in Tunisia, some people in rural areas are still following a traditional life style and surviving with the little things they have. People in the big cities also like to come back to the villages, where they can enjoy the peace and serenity of the nature, and feel connected to the old habits such as cooking on the Afiya (fire) and roaming in the wild.

I'm moroccan; one day a friend of me and i decided to give a visit to a teacher friend of us who got the opportunity to teach in a school in an Berber village in the mountainy suburbs of Marrakech, a place that they call Agrda a few kilometres above Ijoukak, it was a journey of 100 kilometres from home to there. Anyway, the friend that i went with has an uncle in that village who after turned out to be guesting us. When we arrived there we met our friend and stayed a little bit in his place the uncle of the other friend came to take us to his place, and when we were in our way there my teacher friend told me that when we get to the house and sit the old man won't let us bend our legs when we sit on the floor, bacause they believe that when you do so that's a sign thatyou're not being comfortable and instead you should sit with your legs straight as if you're in your home, however i wanted to try sitting bending my legs to see the man's reaction when we get home and when i did that he took my legs and straightened them and was saying something in Amazigh language like "feel comfortable" and things like that. People there are trully nice, loving and have th sould of hospitality that lots of people in the cities lack, we were overwhelmed during the 2 days we spent there ❤️

These women are a proud to us, Moroccans; true Moroccans. It is through them we inherited modesty, respect, and hidden love. Although most of Moroccans do not quite express their feelings as in other cultures, yet they would definitely do whatever it takes when it comes to protecting their loved ones. Here are some beautiful verses from the Holy Quran on the creation of the Earth and its beauty.

1 – Surat Luqman: “Do you not see that Allah (swt) has made what is in the heaven and Earth subservient to you and made complete to you His favours outwardly and inwardly?” [31:20]

2 – Surat Al-Teen: “We have indeed created man in the best of moulds.” [95:4]

3 – Surat Al-Sajdah: “He Who created all things in the best way and He began the creation of man from clay.” [32:7]

4 – Surat Aale Imran: “And to Allah belongs the dominion of the Heaven and Earth, and Allah is over all things. Indeed, in the creation of the heavens and earth, and the alternation of the night and the day are signs for those of understanding.” [3:189-190]

5 – Surat Al-Roum: “Devote thyself single-mindedly to the faith, and thus follow the nature designed by Allah, the nature according to which He has fashioned mankind; there is no altering the creation of Allah.” [30:30]

6 – Surat Al-An’am: “And there is no animal that walks upon the Earth nor a bird that flies with its two wings but they are like yourselves; We have not neglected anything in the book, and then to their Lord shall they be gathered.” [6:38]

7 – Surat Luqman: “He created the heavens without pillars as you see them, and put mountains upon the Earth lest it might convulse with you, and H e spread it with animals of all kinds; and We sent down water from the clouds, then caused to grow therein (vegetation) of every noble kind.” [31:10]

8 – Surat Qaf: “And the Earth, We spread it out, and cast therein firmly set mountains and We have made to grow therein of all beautiful kinds; to give sight and as a reminder to every servant who turns to Allah.” [50:7-8]

9 – Surat Al-Raad: “And it is He who spread the Earth and made in it firm mountains and rivers, and of all fruits, he has made in it two kinds; He makes the night cover the day; most surely there are signs in this for a people who reflect.” [13:3]

10 – Surat Al-Raad: “It is He who shows you the lightning, causing fear and hope and who brings up the heavy cloud. And the thunder declares His glory and His praise, and the angels too for awe of Him; and He sends them thunderbolts and smites with them whom He pleases, yet they dispute concerning Allah, and He is mighty in prowess.” [13:13-14]

11 – Surat Al-Anbiyya: “Have those who disbelieved not considered that the heavens and the Earth were a joined entity,  and we separated them and made from water every living thing? Then will they not believe?” [21:30]

12 – Surat Al-Anbiyya: “And We made the sky a protected ceiling, but they, from its signs, are turning away.” [21:32]

13 – Surat Al-Nahl: “He causes to grow for you thereby herbage, and the olives, and the palm trees, and the grapes, and of all the fruits; most surely there is a sign in this for a people who reflect.” [16:11]

14 – Surat Al-Nahl: “And he has made subservient for you the night and the day and the sun and the moon, and the stars are made subservient by his commandment; most surely there are signs in this for a people who ponder.” [16:12]

15 – Surat Al-Nahl: “Eat of all the fruits and walk in the ways of your lord submissively. there comes forth from within it a beverage of many colours, in which there is healing for men; most surely there is a sign in this (life of bees) for a people who reflect.” [16:69]

16 – Surat Al-An’am: “And it is He who sends down rain from the sky, and We produce thereby the growth of all things. We produce from it greenery from which We produce grains arranged in layers. And from the palm trees – of its emerging fruit are clusters hanging low. And [We produce] gardens of grapevines and olives and pomegranates, similar yet varied. Look at [each of] its fruit when it yields and [at] its ripening. Indeed in that are signs for a people who believe.” [6:99]

17 – Surat Ghaafir: “It is Allah Who has made for you the earth as a resting place, and the sky as a canopy, and has given you shape and made your shapes beautiful and has provided for you sustenance.” [40:64]

18 – Surat Al-Hijr: “And the Earth; we have spread it forth and made in it firm mountains and caused to grow in it every suitable thing.” [15:19]

2 years ago I toured through the Atlas mountains and surrounding area with my bicycle for 2 weeks and I ate a vegetable tajine at every opportunity, maybe once every 1 or 2 days. It took a week for me to learn that entire families often share a tajine the size of what I usually ate alone. Despite that, I lost 5 kilos in two weeks there. Morocco is great for vegans, by the way! I can also confirm that the Berber people are extremely kind and hospitable. As a male, I had a very different experience and barely interacted with any women. It was nice and interesting to see what the experience is like from the perspective of a woman.
Also, that was top quality content. Thanks!

First of all, thank you deeply and intensely for your feelings and your radiant honesty of sincerity for these unforgettable moments spent in a Berber village lost on the borders of my country.
Morocco is really remains a country apart for its hospitality because in any house and in the most distant of the villages, isolated or even lost in a place that seems at the end of the world, you would even find in families, especially Berber, say also Amazighs, the most modest if not the poorest, a guest room, commonly called the hospitality room.
You would then always be greeted with wide open arms accompanied by a smile that is admittedly shy at first but fundamentally honest and you will be treated like a prince or a precious princess that the whole village will hasten to invite and offer you the dishes. More delicious, more traditional and richest even if these families would have to sacrifice their only lamb, goat or chicken.
I am nevertheless Moroccan but every time I find myself stuck in a small Berber village lost in the great or middle Moroccan Atlas, almost non-existent on official maps, I am always treated as a distinguished guest by families who seem to be on the threshold of Absolute poverty and despite my gene, I still feel a Love and a sense of immeasurable pride to be a child of Morocco; This legendary country for its hospitality and the undeniable authenticity of its people so warm.

This reminds me of my grandads village back in Morocco (I would visit Morocco every summer). As a kid I used to find it boring as I grew up in England and was fortunate enough to live a 'normal' European lifestyle with technology, games etc. As the years went on and I got older, I started to really appreciate the community and simplicity of life in that village. Such a great way to get away from the city in Morocco to which we would spend most our time when over there. Havent been in a few years now due to my studies but when I go back I will probably spend most of my time in the village rather than the city. This video really sparked the feelings that I have for my Grandads village, a special experience that none of my friends here in England can relate to and fortunately for me, my family who live in my grandads home will always welcome me and feed me even though they are less fortunate than me. The reason why we wouldn't just take in a random stranger into our homes in the western world is because we live in such a segregated and independent society structure that almost makes it that we compete with everyone instead of helping each other and that's where these poorer areas of the world excel. They have nothing but are happier than those who have everything. Strange world..

comment:
1:36 I think most Imazighen (plural of Amazigh, which means "free man") would rather be referred to as such. The term "berber" is derived from the derogatory "barbarian" and was given to the people of North Africa by the Romans. So thank you for referring to them as Imazighen for the rest of the video.
7:09 Wow, I never heard of bread being made this way in Morocco! I've never even seen a tandoor in Morocco. The only Amazigh style bread I know of is "aghroum tafernout", which is baked on hot pebbles in an oven https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=41IxQzxkNug
9:38 Hands can say a lot about a person. The rougher the hands the softer the soul. :)
10:46 Thank you for being so open minded towards other cultures even though their norms might seem very backwards compared to your own culture and not letting a different way of life prevent you from connecting to people on a human level.
11:09 Having been in the Atlas region in wintertime myself I can confirm how cold it gets. The houses are optimized to stay cool during the hot summers and I still don't understand how these people do it. I'm guessing the good food and plenty of physical activity and sunshine will have to something with it. My oreo-and-instant-noodles ass was freezing off, that's for sure!
11:59 https://forvo.com/word/%D9%82%D9%87%D9%88%D8%A9/
12:24 For those wondering that's cold pressed moroccan olive oil. Delicious in taste and will keep you going for a while before you're hungry again. Bread is the main staple and eaten with every meal. As you can see at 17:47 meals sizes are not very big.
15:00 Easy cowgirl, those were at least 3 Moroccan sips you still had there! ;)
16:05 In Morocco Tajine is served with bread. Couscous is a whole different dish.

Jebel Irhoud (Moroccan Arabic: جبل إيغود‎, romanized: ǧabal īġūd pronounced [ʒbəl ˈiɣud] also Adrar Ighud, Berber: Adrar n Iɣud) is an archaeological site located just north of the locality known as Tlet Ighoud, about 50 km (30 mi) south-east of the city of Safi in Morocco. It is noted for the hominin fossils that have been found there since the site's discovery in 1960. Originally thought to be Neanderthals, the specimens have since been assigned to Homo sapiens and have been dated to roughly 300,000 years ago (286±32 ka for the Irhoud 3 mandible, 315±34 ka based on other fossils and the flint artefacts found nearby).
Link:https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jebel_Irhoud

The term originates from the Greek: βάρβαρος (barbaros pl. βάρβαροι barbaroi). In Ancient Greece, the Greeks used the term towards those who did not speak Greek and follow classical Greek customs.[2] In Ancient Rome, the Romans used the term towards tribal non-Romans such as the Germanics, Celts, Gauls, Iberians, Thracians, Illyrians, Berbers, and Sarmatians. In the early modern period and sometimes later, the Byzantine Greeks used it for the Turks in a clearly pejorative manner.

Tamazgha (Berber: Tamazɣa ⵜⴰⵎⴰⵣⵖⴰ) is a toponym in Berber languages denoting the lands traditionally inhabited by Berbers and which can also mean lands of the Imaziɣen in northern Africa. The region encompasses the geographical area between the Mediterranean Sea and the Niger River, a large swathe of territory spanning Morocco, Algeria, Tunisia, Libya, Mauritania, Mali, Niger, Egypt, Western Sahara, and the Canary Islands.[1]

The Berber flag (Berber language: Akenyal Amaziɣ, ⴰⴾⴻⵏⵢⴰⵍ ⴰⵎⴰⵣⵉⵗ) is a flag that has been adopted by many Berber populations including protestors, cultural and political activists. It is currently used by Berber political and cultural activists and organizations in 10 African countries, namely: Morocco, Algeria, Tunisia, Libya, Mauritania, Mali, Niger, Burkina Faso, Egypt and the Canary Islands.
The flag was inaugurated in Wadya, a town of Kabylia situated in Tizi Wezzu, a province of Algeria, by an elder Algerian Kabylian veteran, Youcef Medkour

The flag is composed of blue, green, and yellow horizontal bands of the same height, and a Tifinagh letter yaz or aza.
ach colour corresponds to an aspect of Tamazgha, the territory inhabited by Berbers in North Africa:

blue represents the Mediterranean Sea and the Atlantic Ocean;

green represents nature and the green mountains;

yellow represents the sands of the Sahara Desert.

The Yaz (ⵣ) symbolizes the Amazigh motto : "Free Man, Free Woman. Free People". The Berbers' own name for themselves (endonym). It is in red, the colour of life.
The Berber flag thus symbolizes the entire Amazigh people, living in harmony with their land, Tamazgha
Link:https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berber_flag

Eva, again you prove you are the best travel-blogger on the planet. Your appreciation of all peoples is gorgeous, and should be a mandatory viewing lesson for people round the  globe. Sadly, I know far too many people in my Britain who fear people who do not look/speak like them. Yet, tragically, the situation is far worse in the USA.  As an academic, I am constantly battling the plague of narrow-mindedness. Yet, it is pushing a bolder uphill. The root of that condition is fear, and it is irrational. In fact, it's vicious! I can relate my travel experiences to the inflicted, even my superb story of traveling to Berlin from university in Nice, France to be part of the historical party in November of 1989. Yet, most react with surprise, shock and fear. All that, despite my telling them that the moment, though sad, was also filled with joy. Thus, sparked by your constant theme of appreciating all cultures, I shall endeavour to record a video lecture on humanity, and the importance of treasuring it greatly.  Cheers & ta!

In 1993 we were given safe harbor in a small Berber village in the Mid Atlas mountains near Khenifra after experiencing a breakdown on one of the isolated mountain roads late at night. They fed us, gave us shelter and unbeknownst to us towed and fixed our vehicle. They refused any renumeration for their efforts. If anything were slightly offended by our persistence at offering them dinars for their trouble. We ended up giving their children some printed tee shirts. They were thrilled with the gifts. To this day I think of the generosity of a culture that lives with so little yet gave so much to help total strangers.

Jebel Irhoud (Moroccan Arabic: جبل إيغود‎, romanized: ǧabal īġūd pronounced [ʒbəl ˈiɣud] also Adrar Ighud, Berber: Adrar n Iɣud) is an archaeological site located just north of the locality known as Tlet Ighoud, about 50 km (30 mi) south-east of the city of Safi in Morocco. It is noted for the hominin fossils that have been found there since the site's discovery in 1960. Originally thought to be Neanderthals, the specimens have since been assigned to Homo sapiens and have been dated to roughly 300,000 years ago (286±32 ka for the Irhoud 3 mandible, 315±34 ka based on other fossils and the flint artefacts found nearby).
Link:https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jebel_Irhoud

Saint Monica (c.331/2−387)[1] (AD 322–387)[2] was an early African Christian saint and the mother of St. Augustine of Hippo. She is remembered and honored in the Catholic and Orthodox Churches, albeit on different feast days, for her outstanding Christian virtues, particularly the suffering caused by her husband's adultery, and her prayerful life dedicated to the reformation of her son, who wrote extensively of her pious acts and life with her in his Confessions. Popular Christian legends recall Saint Monica weeping every night for her son Augustine.

Saint


Monica of Hippo


Mother of Saint Augustine of Hippo
Born332
Thagaste, Numidia, Roman Empire (present day Souk Ahras, Algeria)Died387
Ostia, Italy, Roman Empire
Link:https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saint_Monica

Augustine of Hippo (/ɔːˈɡʌstɪn/; Latin: Aurelius Augustinus Hipponensis; 13 November 354 – 28 August 430 AD),[18] also known as Saint Augustine, was a theologian, philosopher, and the bishop of Hippo Regius in Numidia, Roman North Africa. His writings influenced the development of Western philosophy and Western Christianity, and he is viewed as one of the most important Church Fathers of the Latin Church in the Patristic Period. His many important works include The City of God, On Christian Doctrine, and Confessions.
Link:https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Augustine_of_Hippo

Second Punic War

The Second Punic War (spring 218 – 201 BC),[3][4] also referred to as The Hannibalic War and by the Romans the War Against Hannibal, was the second of three Punic Wars between the Roman Republic and Carthage, with the participation of Macedonia and Syracuse polities and Numidian and Iberian forces on both sides. It was one of the deadliest human conflicts of ancient times. Fought across the entire Western Mediterranean region for 17 years and regarded by Livy as the greatest war in history, it was waged with unparalleled resources, skill, and hatred.[5]:21.1 It saw hundreds of thousands killed, some of the most lethal battles in military history, the destruction of cities, and massacres and enslavements of civilian populations and prisoners of war by both sides.
Link:https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Second_Punic_War
The Numidian cavalry's horses, ancestors of the Berber horse, were small compared to other horses of the era, and were well adapted for faster movement over long distances.[2] Numidian horsemen rode without saddles or bridles, controlling their mounts with a simple rope around their horse's neck and a small riding stick. They had no form of bodily protection except for a round leather shield or a leopard skin, and their main weapon were javelins in addition to a short sword.[3]
Due to their expert horsemanship and agility, as well as their lack of armor or heavy weaponry, they were most suitable for harassing tactics, charging in loose formation and lobbing their javelins before wheeling off to escape the enemy's counterattack. This harassing tactic, while rarely decisive, could be extremely frustrating to a less mobile enemy, as experienced by Julius Caesar's soldiers during the latter's invasion of Africa. At the same time they were generally unable to stand their ground against heavier types of cavalry. In one incident during the aforementioned African invasion thirty of Caesar's Gallic horsemen drove off a much larger force of Moorish cavalry, while in another a squadron of Caesar's heavy Iberian horsemen routed a large body of Labienus's Numidians, while his Gallic and Germanic horsemen stood their ground.
The Numidians were extremely useful during small wars, and their presence certainly contributed greatly to the effectiveness of Hannibal's reconnaissance and intelligence. Hannibal's invasion of Rome during the Second Punic War is best known for his use of slow-moving war elephants, but he also employed Numidian cavalry where faster movement was needed, such as luring the Romans into a trap at the Battle of Trebia[4] and for fighting on his right flank.
Numidian cavalry were widely known and not only fought in the Carthaginian army, but in other armies of the time as well – the Romans even employed Numidian cavalry against Hannibal's own in the battle of Zama,[5] where the "Numidian Cavalry turned the scales".[6]
For centuries thereafter, the Roman army employed Numidian light cavalry in separate units (equites Numidarum or Maurorum).
https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Numidian_cavalry

When I was born in the High Atlas moutants of Morocco in 1985 there was much less than today. My mother told me that I was very sick the first month of my life. My father was already in the Netherlands so that he could save mony for us. Everybody in the small village was crying because the thougt that I was gonna die. And one day a olderly woman came to our village end asked my aunt why she was crying? She told her about me and asked my aunt to bring her to my mother who was day and night with me. She told my mother to trust here and wat to do. She cleaned my throat with oil and a feather of a bird and wrapped my in a lot of blankeds. She also told my mother to heat up the room a lot. And wonderfully since that day every day I got better and better after being sick for over a month. She saved my life like a doctor would do. When I was 12 I was in the village in Morocco and my mother told me, do you know this lady? Ofcourse I din't and she told me that she saved my life.

The reaseaon I'm telling you this is to let you understand how simpel life is over there. People are greatfull with wat they have. And don't think that they are not happy because they have not what we have in Europe or in the west. We are known as berbers but actually we are Amazigh, what means free people. And that is precise what they have. Freedom to live as they want, food and a verry simpel live. As you know even they haven't a lot. They will always share everthing they have and even more nomatter who you are. That's the real life🙂🙃.

May god bless you with what you have.

Exactly my experience. I lived with a Berber family for 6 weeks, about 8 yrs ago and I still think about those days and nights. It's a really hard life and they had nothing but the kindness they showed me was indescribable. One of the most memorable, special experiences of my life. We put water on the roof to heat up (by the sun) and slept in those heavy blankets with no electricity. And the stars at night...wow! It made me very grateful for what I have and the best part was being able to help them and others (I lived there for 2 yrs). It's desperately difficult for them now with no tourists or work and Covid. Everything you said here Eva is so true...loved watching this it brought all those memories back.Yours is  my favourite YouTube channel, kudos to you for your bravery, adventurous and positive spirit and taking us to all these incredible places...
